segment.source: Use the AppLocker Windows PowerShell cmdlets (Windows 10)
segment.target: Use the AppLocker Windows PowerShell cmdlets (Windows 10)

segment.source: This topic for IT professionals describes how each AppLocker Windows PowerShell cmdlet can help you administer your AppLocker application control policies.
segment.target: This topic for IT professionals describes how each AppLocker Windows PowerShell cmdlet can help you administer your AppLocker application control policies.

segment.source: Use the AppLocker Windows PowerShell cmdlets
segment.target: Use the AppLocker Windows PowerShell cmdlets

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: This topic for IT professionals describes how each AppLocker Windows PowerShell cmdlet can help you administer your AppLocker application control policies.
segment.target: This topic for IT professionals describes how each AppLocker Windows PowerShell cmdlet can help you administer your AppLocker application control policies.

segment.source: AppLocker Windows PowerShell cmdlets
segment.target: AppLocker Windows PowerShell cmdlets

segment.source: The five AppLocker cmdlets are designed to streamline the administration of an AppLocker policy.
segment.target: The five AppLocker cmdlets are designed to streamline the administration of an AppLocker policy.

segment.source: They can be used to help create, test, maintain, and troubleshoot an AppLocker policy.
segment.target: They can be used to help create, test, maintain, and troubleshoot an AppLocker policy.

segment.source: The cmdlets are intended to be used in conjunction with the AppLocker user interface that is accessed through the Microsoft Management Console (MMC) snap-in extension to the Local Security Policy snap-in and Group Policy Management Console.
segment.target: The cmdlets are intended to be used in conjunction with the AppLocker user interface that is accessed through the Microsoft Management Console (MMC) snap-in extension to the Local Security Policy snap-in and Group Policy Management Console.

segment.source: To edit or update a Group Policy Object (GPO) by using the AppLocker cmdlets, you must have Edit Setting permission.
segment.target: To edit or update a Group Policy Object (GPO) by using the AppLocker cmdlets, you must have Edit Setting permission.

segment.source: By default, members of the Domain Admins group, the Enterprise Admins group, and the Group Policy Creator Owners group have this permission.
segment.target: By default, members of the Domain Admins group, the Enterprise Admins group, and the Group Policy Creator Owners group have this permission.

segment.source: To perform tasks by using the Local Security policy snap-in, you must be a member of the local Administrators group, or equivalent, on the computer.
segment.target: To perform tasks by using the Local Security policy snap-in, you must be a member of the local Administrators group, or equivalent, on the computer.

segment.source: Retrieve application information
segment.target: Retrieve application information

segment.source: The Get-AppLockerFileInformation cmdlet retrieves the AppLocker file information from a list of files or from an event log.
segment.target: The Get-AppLockerFileInformation cmdlet retrieves the AppLocker file information from a list of files or from an event log.

segment.source: File information that is retrieved can include publisher information, file hash information, and file path information.
segment.target: File information that is retrieved can include publisher information, file hash information, and file path information.

segment.source: File information from an event log may not contain all of these fields.
segment.target: File information from an event log may not contain all of these fields.

segment.source: Files that are not signed do not have any publisher information.
segment.target: Files that are not signed do not have any publisher information.

segment.source: Set AppLocker policy
segment.target: Set AppLocker policy

segment.source: The Set-AppLockerPolicy cmdlet sets the specified GPO to contain the specified AppLocker policy.
segment.target: The Set-AppLockerPolicy cmdlet sets the specified GPO to contain the specified AppLocker policy.

segment.source: If no Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP) is specified, the local GPO is the default.
segment.target: If no Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP) is specified, the local GPO is the default.

segment.source: Retrieve an AppLocker policy
segment.target: Retrieve an AppLocker policy

segment.source: The Get-AppLockerPolicy cmdlet gets the AppLocker policy from the local GPO, from a specified GPO, or from the effective AppLocker policy on the device.
segment.target: The Get-AppLockerPolicy cmdlet gets the AppLocker policy from the local GPO, from a specified GPO, or from the effective AppLocker policy on the device.

segment.source: The output of the AppLocker policy is an AppLockerPolicy object or an XML-formatted string.
segment.target: The output of the AppLocker policy is an AppLockerPolicy object or an XML-formatted string.

segment.source: Generate rules for a given user or group
segment.target: Generate rules for a given user or group

segment.source: The New-AppLockerPolicy cmdlet uses a list of file information to automatically generate rules for a given user or group.
segment.target: The New-AppLockerPolicy cmdlet uses a list of file information to automatically generate rules for a given user or group.

segment.source: It can generate rules based on publisher, hash, or path information.
segment.target: It can generate rules based on publisher, hash, or path information.

segment.source: Use Get-AppLockerFileInformation to create the list of file information.
segment.target: Use Get-AppLockerFileInformation to create the list of file information.

segment.source: Test the AppLocker Policy against a file set
segment.target: Test the AppLocker Policy against a file set

segment.source: The Test-AppLockerPolicy cmdlet uses the specified AppLocker policy to test whether a specified list of files are allowed to run or not on the local device for a specific user.
segment.target: The Test-AppLockerPolicy cmdlet uses the specified AppLocker policy to test whether a specified list of files are allowed to run or not on the local device for a specific user.

segment.source: Additional resources
segment.target: Additional resources

segment.source: For steps to perform other AppLocker policy tasks, see Administer AppLocker.
segment.target: For steps to perform other AppLocker policy tasks, see Administer AppLocker.
